message:
That's what I understood you to mean.

To put my arguments another way:

Conceptually, an entire method will run in a context (unless it uses ConfigureAwait(false)). It won't start out in one context and then jump to a threadpool context when it hits an await.

Practically, a demo that just uses "await" has more wow power than a demo that uses "await" with "ConfigureAwait(true)". The ConfigureAwait would distract from the demo.
